Amniotic Fluid Infection Sequence (Mater.name: Amniotic Fluid Infection Sequence (Maternal and Fetal Inflammatory Response)

Terminology.text: Amniotic fluid infection sequence (AFIS)Maternal and fetal inflammatory responses to ascending infection of amniotic cavity by cervicovaginal floraMaternal response seen in membranes, chorionic plateFetal response in umbilical and chorionic plate vasculitis
sub_points: Maternal and fetal inflammatory responses to ascending infection of amniotic cavity by cervicovaginal flora
Maternal response seen in membranes, chorionic plate
Fetal response in umbilical and chorionic plate vasculitis

Terminology.text: Intraamniotic inflammation, infection, or both (triple I)Term proposed to replace clinical (not histologic) diagnosis of chorioamnionitis
sub_points: Term proposed to replace clinical (not histologic) diagnosis of chorioamnionitis

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Preterm chorioamnionitis: Higher rate of positive cultures
Term chorioamnionitis: Frequently has negative cultures and negative bacterial PCR, (sterile intraamniotic inflammation)

Clinical Issues.text: 66-75% of women with significant inflammation within membranes are asymptomatic
Nearly 40% of premature births associated with histologic chorioamnionitis
Higher grade and stage of maternal and fetal inflammatory responses → higher risk of neonatal infection

Microscopic.text: Maternal and fetal acute inflammatory responses graded for severity and staged for extent and implied duration of response
Bacteria are rarely identified within membranes; their presence indicates heavy colonization

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Decidual leukocytoclastic necrosis: More similar to laminar decidual necrosis than AFIS

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Placental pathology showing maternal and fetal inflammatory responses confirms suspected diagnosis of triple I.

Abbreviations.text: Intraamniotic infection, inflammation, or both (triple I)

Definitions.text: AFIS: Progression of maternal and fetal inflammatory responses (FIR) to ascending infection of amniotic cavity by cervicovaginal floraGrade: Severity of inflammationStage: Chronicity, implied from progression of inflammation through tissue layers
sub_points: Grade: Severity of inflammation
Stage: Chronicity, implied from progression of inflammation through tissue layers

Definitions.text: Maternal inflammatory response (MIR): Maternal neutrophils reacting to stimuli in amniotic fluidGrade 1 (mild, moderate): Defined as not severeGrade 2 (severe): Severe acute chorioamnionitis, ± subchorionic microabscesses, > 10 x 20 confluent neutrophils in at least 3 foci or in continuous band of membrane rollStage 1 (early): Acute subchorionitis or chorionitisStage 2 (intermediate): Acute chorioamnionitis, neutrophils in fibrous chorion &/or amnionStage 3 (advanced): Necrosis of amnion, amnion basement membrane thickening/hypereosinophilia, karyorrhexis of neutrophils
sub_points: Grade 1 (mild, moderate): Defined as not severe
Grade 2 (severe): Severe acute chorioamnionitis, ± subchorionic microabscesses, > 10 x 20 confluent neutrophils in at least 3 foci or in continuous band of membrane roll
Stage 1 (early): Acute subchorionitis or chorionitis
Stage 2 (intermediate): Acute chorioamnionitis, neutrophils in fibrous chorion &/or amnion
Stage 3 (advanced): Necrosis of amnion, amnion basement membrane thickening/hypereosinophilia, karyorrhexis of neutrophils

Definitions.text: FIR: Fetal neutrophils reacting to stimuliGrade 1 (mild, moderate): Defined as not severeGrade 2 (severe): Near confluent neutrophils in fetal vessels with attenuation of vascular smooth muscleStage 1 (early): Chorionic plate vasculitis or umbilical vein phlebitisStage 2 (intermediate): Inflammation of 1 or both arteries ± inflammation of veinStage 3 (advanced): Necrotizing funisitis (subacute) with neutrophils and debris (sometimes calcified) forming arcs oriented towards amnion surface around 1 or more vessels
sub_points: Grade 1 (mild, moderate): Defined as not severe
Grade 2 (severe): Near confluent neutrophils in fetal vessels with attenuation of vascular smooth muscle
Stage 1 (early): Chorionic plate vasculitis or umbilical vein phlebitis
Stage 2 (intermediate): Inflammation of 1 or both arteries ± inflammation of vein
Stage 3 (advanced): Necrotizing funisitis (subacute) with neutrophils and debris (sometimes calcified) forming arcs oriented towards amnion surface around 1 or more vessels

Definitions.text: FIR syndromeClinical diagnosis, elevated fetal IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, G-CSF with increased neutrophils and enhanced erythropoiesis
sub_points: Clinical diagnosis, elevated fetal IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, G-CSF with increased neutrophils and enhanced erythropoiesis

Presentation.text: 66-75% of women with histologic chorioamnionitis are asymptomatic

Histologic chorioamnionitis is more frequent in preterm placentas40-50% < 27 weeks, 15% at 28-36 weeks, 2-10% at termPreterm placentas often have chorionic plate vasculitis as initial fetal responseTerm placentas often have inflammation of umbilical vein as initial fetal response
sub_points: 40-50% < 27 weeks, 15% at 28-36 weeks, 2-10% at term
Preterm placentas often have chorionic plate vasculitis as initial fetal response
Term placentas often have inflammation of umbilical vein as initial fetal response

Treatment.text: Once inflammatory cascade is activated, it is not stopped or reversed by antibiotics or tocolytics
Antibiotics reduce risk of maternal sepsis and early-onset fetal sepsis and may delay delivery by a few days

Prognosis.text: Chorioamnionitis may result in dysfunctional uterine contractions, ↑ incidence of cesarean section, ↑ risk for postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony

FIR is associated with FIR syndrome with neonatal morbidity and risk of neurologic injuryMechanisms of brain injury include cytokines, ischemia, and toxic injury by bacterial products or actual infection
sub_points: Mechanisms of brain injury include cytokines, ischemia, and toxic injury by bacterial products or actual infection

Prognosis.text: Meconium passage often accompanies chorioamnionitis

General Features.text: Chorioamnionitis is often not recognized grossly
Subacute chorioamnionitis has opaque yellow-white membranes
Necrotizing funisitis may have barber pole appearance due to necrotic/calcified debris
Candidafunisitis has subamniotic yellow-white microabscesses on umbilical cord

Histologic Features.text: Description of severity (grade) and location (stage) of inflammation of MIR and FIR provides clinically useful informationHigher grades and stages of both MIR and FIR have higher incidence of neonatal infectionBacteria are rarely identified within membranes; their presence indicates heavy colonization
sub_points: Higher grades and stages of both MIR and FIR have higher incidence of neonatal infection
Bacteria are rarely identified within membranes; their presence indicates heavy colonization

Placental Cultures.text: Rarely positive and frequently contaminated with vaginal flora; organisms may be difficult to culture

Gram or Other More Specific Stains.text: May be helpful when organisms visible on routine H&E

Chronic Chorioamnionitis.text: Rarely due to amniotic fluid infectionAssociated with chronic villitis of unknown etiology
sub_points: Associated with chronic villitis of unknown etiology

T-Cell Lymphocytic and Eosinophilic Vasc.text: Fetal chorionic plate vasculitis often oriented toward intervillous space, not amniotropic, not associated with infection

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Pathologic diagnosis should include MIR and FIR findings with full histologic terminology, that clearly describes the stage and grade

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Most term babies with MIR and FIR have negative blood cultures
Higher stage and more severe grade of MIR and FIR, more likely there will be neonatal infection

Highest yield of positive placental cultures in preterm premature ruptured membranesPositive placental cultures are associated with increased incidence of respiratory distress and positive neonatal cultures
sub_points: Positive placental cultures are associated with increased incidence of respiratory distress and positive neonatal cultures

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Widely present in environment as a saprophytic organism
Most infections are food-borne and have been associated with fruits and vegetables, deli meats, smoked meats, and unpasteurized milk and cheese
Clinically relevant species includeListeria monocytogenesandListeria ivanovii
Classified into 3 general syndromesFebrile gastroenteritisMaternal-fetal/neonatal listeriosisBacteremia ± CNS involvement
sub_points: Febrile gastroenteritis
Maternal-fetal/neonatal listeriosis
Bacteremia ± CNS involvement

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Strong tropism for central nervous system

Microscopic Features.text: CNS: Meningitis, encephalitis, and abscess
Liver: Granulomas and abscesses can be found in liver as consequence of bloodstream sequestration followed by escape and replication

Definitions.text: Named in honor of English surgeon Joseph Lister (1827-1912)

Environmental Exposure.text: Widely present in environment as a saprophytic organism
Most infections are food-borne and have been associated with fruits and vegetables, deli meats, smoked meats, and unpasteurized milk and cheese
Listeriais particularly a problem in food contamination because of its ability to multiply at refrigeration temperatures
Some nosocomial (NICU) outbreaks have been reported

Infectious Agents.text: Clinically relevant species includeListeria monocytogenesandListeria ivanovii
Contains large number of stress response genes, which allow it to survive in wide variety of environments
Facultative intracellular pathogen employing several virulence factors allowing it to escape from phagosome, replicate within host cell cytoplasm, and invade neighboring cells

Highly accomplished neuroinvasive pathogenAble to invade CNS by transport across BBB within host immune cells, direct invasion of endothelial cells, and retrograde movement up axons of involved nerves
sub_points: Able to invade CNS by transport across BBB within host immune cells, direct invasion of endothelial cells, and retrograde movement up axons of involved nerves

Epidemiology.text: Disease is most severe at extremes of age, in immunosuppressed, and in pregnant women
Causes 1,600 illnesses and 260 deaths annually in USA
From 1998-2008, an average of 2.2 outbreaks per year were reported in USA

Presentation.text: Classified into 3 general syndromes: Febrile gastroenteritis, maternal-fetal/neonatal listeriosis, and bacteremia ± CNS involvementFebrile gastroenteritisTypically occurs in immunocompetent patients after 5-49 hour incubationSymptoms include diarrhea, fever, abdominal pain, chills, and headacheMaternal-fetal/neonatal listeriosisGenerally presents as bacteremia (fever, chills, headache) in motherMay induce stillbirth or abortion in ~ 20% of pregnanciesCan also cause preterm delivery and neonatal infectionNeonate can be exposed though placental hematogenous seeding or through contact in birth canalDisease in neonate can be early or lateEarly disease (infection before delivery) manifests as pneumonia, meningitis, or bacteremia; signs include meconium staining, respiratory distress, fever, lethargy, jaundice, and rash; may be accompanied by microabscesses concentrated in lungs, liver, and spleen (granulomatosis infantiseptica)Late disease (infection at time of delivery from uncomplicated pregnancy) manifests as meningitisBacteremia ± CNS involvementCNS involvement is present in ~ 50% of patientsManifestations include meningitis, meningoencephalitis, brainstem encephalitis, and brain abscessSymptoms include fever, headache, and mental status changes with meningeal signs in ~ 1/2 of patientsBrainstem encephalitis (10% of infections) starts with prodrome of headache, nausea, vomiting, and fever followed by brainstem, cerebellar, and long tract signs/dysfunctionPatients with abscess generally present with fever, headache, and focal neurological signsOther manifestations include focal infections from hematogenous spread
sub_points: Febrile gastroenteritisTypically occurs in immunocompetent patients after 5-49 hour incubationSymptoms include diarrhea, fever, abdominal pain, chills, and headache

Late disease (infection at time of delivery from uncomplicated pregnancy) manifests as meningitis

Manifestations include meningitis, meningoencephalitis, brainstem encephalitis, and brain abscess
Symptoms include fever, headache, and mental status changes with meningeal signs in ~ 1/2 of patients
Brainstem encephalitis (10% of infections) starts with prodrome of headache, nausea, vomiting, and fever followed by brainstem, cerebellar, and long tract signs/dysfunction
Patients with abscess generally present with fever, headache, and focal neurological signs
Other manifestations include focal infections from hematogenous spread

Presentation.text: Cutaneous listeriosis is thought to result from contact with infected animals (generally occupational) though it may, in rare cases, result from bacteremia

Laboratory Tests.text: CSF analysis: With meningitis/meningoencephalitis, Gram stain is positive in < 30% of cases, but cultures are positive in 80%; with abscess, culture is positive in < 1/2
Cervix, amniotic fluid, and placental cultures may reveal organism in maternal listeriosis

Treatment.text: Gastroenteritis is self-limited and should subside in 3-4 days without antibiotics
For invasive disease, ampicillin or penicillin along with gentamicin are drugs of choice; cephalosporins are not recommended due to high level of resistance

Prognosis.text: Mortality averages 36% with CNS involvement

Morphological and Biochemical Characteri.text: Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, facultative anaerobe shaped as short rods arranged as singles or short chains
Demonstrates characteristic tumbling motility, particularly at 20-28° C due to temperature-regulated flagella
Most strains produce catalase, though oxidase is not produced
Positive assays include catalase, Voges-Proskauer (acetoin production), methyl red (acidic fermentation products), and esculin hydrolysis

Culture.text: Listeriaare nonfastidious and typically isolated on blood agar, where they demonstrate a small zone of beta-hemolysis (sometimes difficult to appreciate) due to bacterial production of hemolysin

Selective and differential agars forListeriainclude LPM (colonies are blue), Oxford and PALCAM (selective via lithium and antibiotics and differential via esculin hydrolysis: Colonies are black), as well as several chromogenic agars (i.e., Oxoid Brilliance, which can also differentiate betweenL. monocytogenesandL. ivanovii)
L. monocytogenesand L. ivanoviican also be differentiated based on the induction of beta-hemolysis by eitherStaphylococcus aureusorRhodococcus equi(respectively) in  CAMP test
Isolation from food may require enrichment steps

Microbiological Identification.text: Listeriacan be classified down to species level with Vitek 2 platform
Other rapid technologies for identifying listeria include DNA probes (AccuProbe, Biomérieux) and MALDI-TOF

General Features.text: Placental infection can be indicated by yellowish membranes with fruity odor and large abscesses

Histologic Features.text: CNS: Meningitis, encephalitis, and abscess
Liver: Granulomas and abscesses can be found in liver with bloodstream sequestration followed by escape and replication

Placenta: Fetal infection by hematogenous spread from maternal circulation to placenta may demonstrate acute villitis, abscesses and granulomas (granulomatosis infantisepticum), and necrotizing acute chorioamnionitisOrganisms can be identified by silver or Gram staining
sub_points: Organisms can be identified by silver or Gram staining

Abscess.text: Differentiate from other infectious causes of abscess by culture or molecular diagnosis

Meningitis.text: Other common causes of bacterial meningitis includeStreptococcuspneumoniaeandEscherichia coli
Differentiate by Gram stain, culture, &/or molecular methods

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Most common congenital viral infection, occurring in 1% of newborns
Congenital CMV may be transmitted vertically in utero, at time of delivery by cervical secretions, or through breast milk

Clinical Issues.text: CMV is leading cause of nongenetic sensorineural hearing loss and a leading cause of neurodevelopmental abnormalities in childrenHearing loss is progressive over 1st year; infants may pass hearing screen at birth
sub_points: Hearing loss is progressive over 1st year; infants may pass hearing screen at birth

Clinical Issues.text: 85-90% of infected infants asymptomatic
Central nervous system involvement includes meningoencephalitis, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, hydrocephalus, polymicrogyria, and periventricular calcifications
Infected infants may have pancytopenia with hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, and purpura
Prematurity, hydrops, symmetric intrauterine growth restriction and intrauterine fetal demise with early in utero infection

Microscopic.text: Lymphoplasmacytic villitis
Avascular villi with hemosiderin
Rare viral inclusions in Hofbauer cells and endothelium
Eosinophilic necrotic debris in villi with suspicious viral inclusions

Ancillary Tests.text: Immunohistochemistry for CMV very useful in confirming diagnosis
Unknown whether placental infection always means fetal infection

Infectious Agents.text: Most common congenital viral infection, occurring in 1% of live births

Congenital CMV may be transmitted from mother to child in 3 waysIn utero vertical transmission across placenta (hematogenous spread)30-50% of pregnant women during primary CMV infection1-3% of women with reactivation of CMVIntrapartum transmission by cervical secretionsWomen with primary or reactivated CMV infection may shed virus from cervix50% of women shedding virus from cervix will infect baby during vaginal deliveryPostpartum transmission through breast milk30-70% of women with primary or reactivated CMV infection shed virus in breast milk

Infectious Agents.text: CMV antibody-negative women have 1-2% risk of primary CMV infection during pregnancy

Presentation.text: CMV is leading nongenetic cause of sensorineural hearing loss and a leading cause of neurodevelopmental disabilities in children
85-90% of infected infants are asymptomatic

sub_points: Intrauterine growth restriction, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia with petechiae or purpura

Drugs.text: Treatment with intravenous ganciclovir or oral valganciclovir for symptomatic infants
Treatment of less severely affected or asymptomatic infants not yet routine
Treatment with hyperimmune globulin during pregnancy has not shown efficacy

Prognosis.text: Mortality for symptomatic congenital CMV is ~ 30%
Associated with prematurity, hydrops, intrauterine growth restriction and intrauterine fetal demise
70% of 1st-trimester infections have severe CNS injury
10-17% of asymptomatic infants at birth will develop unilateral or bilateral deafness

General Features.text: Placenta may be hydropic

Avascular villi with hemosiderin

sub_points: May be rare

Immunohistochemistry.text: Anti-CMV antibodies against immediate-early, early, or late viral antigens available
Can be useful in confirming diagnosisSensitivity not 100%If lymphoplasmacytic villitis present, urine culture or other studies of neonate for CMV may be warranted
sub_points: Sensitivity not 100%

PCR.text: PCR for CMV on formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue may be more sensitive than immunohistochemistryHas been negative in placenta of confirmed congenital CMV
sub_points: Has been negative in placenta of confirmed congenital CMV

Other Viral Infections.text: Other viruses of herpes family will have similar intranuclear inclusions, but only CMV has intracytoplasmic inclusions

Fetal Vascular Malperfusion.text: May occur in conjunction with CMV infection, especially when villitis affects proximal stem villi

Neonatal Alloimmune Thrombocytopenia.text: Congenital CMV should be clinically excluded with cultures

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: CMV should always be considered when there is lymphoplasmacytic villitis or hemosiderin deposition

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Parvovirus B19 is single-stranded DNA member of Parvoviridae family
Infection of fetal erythroid precursors results in severe anemia, high-output cardiac failure, and hydrops fetalis
Infection of myocardium may contribute to cardiac dysfunction

Clinical Issues.text: Parvovirus during pregnancy may result in nonimmune hydrops fetalis 4-6 weeks post exposure
Vertical transmission occurs in 33% of women during primary infection
Severe fetal anemia results in high-output cardiac failure
15% of nonimmune hydrops are due to parvovirus
5-10% of in utero infections result in lethal hydrops
Survivors of in utero infection are generally normal with rare cases of neurodevelopmental disability reported

Microscopic.text: PlacentaMild to marked villous edemaIncreased fetal nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs), many with intranuclear basophilic or eosinophilic inclusionsUsually without significant chronic villitis
sub_points: Mild to marked villous edema

Microscopic.text: Fetal findingsLiver is most severely affected often with hemosiderosisBone marrow is hypocellular
sub_points: Liver is most severely affected often with hemosiderosis
Bone marrow is hypocellular

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Marked increase in NRBCs (erythroblastosis fetalis) associated with hydropic pale placenta should prompt search for parvovirus inclusions
Hydropic pale fetus, often with hepatic hemosiderosis is suggestive of parvovirus
Immunohistochemistry is very useful, even in severely macerated tissues

Algorithm for Use in HD Diagnosis.text: Always check hCG and compare to expected normal levels for gestational age

VECHM.text: Atypical implantation site, bulbous cauliflower-like villi, myxoid stroma, abundant karyorrhexis and mixed trophoblast proliferation

PHM.text: 2 villous populations, prominent villous irregularity, trophoblastic pseudoinclusions, central cisterns and syncytiotrophoblast proliferation

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Most important part of grossing specimen is to rinse out blood and float/rehydrate villi in water
Implantation site decidua basalis will confirm intrauterine pregnancy in absence of villi

Terminology.text: Partial hydatidiform mole (PHM)
Diandric triploidy: 3 sets of chromosomes (2 paternal, 1 maternal)
Digynic triploidy: 3 sets of chromosomes (1 paternal, 2 maternal)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: PHM is triploid gestation with 2 paternal genomes and 1 maternal genome (diandric triploidy)Triploidy can also be composed of 2 maternal genomes and 1 paternal genome (digynic triploidy): These are not associated with PHM
sub_points: Triploidy can also be composed of 2 maternal genomes and 1 paternal genome (digynic triploidy): These are not associated with PHM

Enlarged, irregular, dysmorphic villi with trophoblast inclusions
Enlarged villi with cisterns (at least 3 mm in size)
Syncytiotrophoblast hyperplasia/atypia

Microscopic.text: Nonmolar triploidy (digynic triploidy) may show some of these features but not significant syncytiotrophoblast hyperplasia

Definitions.text: Diandric triploidy: 3 sets of chromosomes (2 paternal, 1 maternal)
Digynic triploidy: 3 sets of chromosomes (2 maternal, 1 paternal)
Androgenetic conception: Chromosomes from paternal origin only
Androgenetic/biparental mosaic conception: Mixed population where some cell lineages have only paternal chromosomes, other cell lineages have both maternal and paternal chromosomes
Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD): PHM, CHM, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, epithelioid trophoblastic tumor, placenta site trophoblastic tumor

Evolution of fibrinoid necrosis may be due to ischemia, endothelial damage from circulating factors such as s-Flt1 and sEng, aberrant Th1 responses, or susceptibility of unremodeled muscular vessels to effects of late pregnancy

Decidual Arteriopathy.text: Perivascular lymphocytes (chronic perivasculitis) may accompany any of these changes

Absence of SA Remodeling.text: Trophoblast cells normally remodel preplacental SA in decidua basalis and underlying myometrium
Spiral arteries that do not remodel are susceptible to fibrinoid necrosis and acute atherosisIncludes all membranous decidual vessels, and basal vessels that did not remodel
sub_points: Includes all membranous decidual vessels, and basal vessels that did not remodel

Absence of SA Remodeling.text: Small basilar branches of spiral arteries at decidua basalis do not undergo adaptation (including arcuate arteries)

Mural Hypertrophy.text: SA and veins throughout decidua have attenuation of vascular smooth muscle early in pregnancy
When SA thinning fails, vessels remain thickAssociated with preexisting vascular disease such as hypertension and diabetes
sub_points: Associated with preexisting vascular disease such as hypertension and diabetes

Mural Hypertrophy.text: May be evident in cases that otherwise have appropriate trophoblast-mediated remodeling in decidua basalis

Progresses to fibrinoid necrosis in some cases, usually with small-for-age fetal growth ± preeclampsiaVascular smooth muscle fragments on desmin stainingEndothelial cells swell, begin to see CD34, CD31 granular staining in media
sub_points: Vascular smooth muscle fragments on desmin staining
Endothelial cells swell, begin to see CD34, CD31 granular staining in media

Fibrinoid necrosis.text: Smooth muscle is degenerated with minimal desmin staining, regular nuclei of vascular smooth muscle replaced by fibrin
Granular staining of CD34 and CD31 in media is pronounced
Foam cells (foamy macrophages) may or may not be present adjacent to or within vessel wall

Acute Atherosis.text: Advanced stage of fibrinoid necrosis with subendothelial and mural foam cellsMay be late effort to remodel vessels, immune-mediated effect, or effect of other soluble factor
sub_points: May be late effort to remodel vessels, immune-mediated effect, or effect of other soluble factor

Acute Atherosis.text: Despite name and appearance, pathogenesis is not related to atherosclerosis

Persistence of Endovascular Trophoblast.text: Endovascular trophoblast is normal in 1st and 2nd trimester, over time trophoblastic cells invade vessels and no longer persist in the lumen

Reason for their presence in 3rd trimester is unclear, possibilities includeDelay of remodeling processIncreased production of extravillous trophoblast from anchoring villiInhibited migration down vessel and through wall
sub_points: Delay of remodeling process
Increased production of extravillous trophoblast from anchoring villi
Inhibited migration down vessel and through wall

Incidence.text: Occurs in < 1% of uncomplicated pregnancies

More frequent in pregnancies with fetal growth restriction with or without preeclampsiaFibrinoid necrosis, acute atherosis most common in SGA with preeclampsia and abnormal Dopplers of umbilical vessels
sub_points: Fibrinoid necrosis, acute atherosis most common in SGA with preeclampsia and abnormal Dopplers of umbilical vessels

Prognosis.text: Associated with recurrent indicated preterm birth

General Features.text: DA is not visible grosslyLarge thrombi of decidual vessels may be seen on gross exam
sub_points: Large thrombi of decidual vessels may be seen on gross exam

Mimics.text: Entrapped villi in basal fibrin with muscular fetal vessels mimic muscular maternal vessels in basal plate

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Understanding normal vascular remodeling is key to appreciating DA

Terminology.text: Infarct: Ischemic tissue necrosis of villous parenchyma due to maternal vascular malperfusion
Marginal infarct: Infarct located within acute angle of disc margin, ~ 1 cm of disc margin
Infarction hematoma: Infarct with rounded hemorrhage in center of lesion

Clinical Issues.text: Marginal infarcts seen in healthy term deliveries, associated with older maternal age
Multiple central infarcts associated with small-for-gestational-age fetal growth, severe preeclampsia
Extensive infarction associated with neonatal asphyxia and fetal demise

Macroscopic.text: Placenta is often small for age
Recent infarct: Dark red, firm lesion
Subacute to remote infarct: Pale, tan, firm area with granular consistency
Infarction hematoma: Rounded hematoma surrounded by rim of firm parenchyma
Infarcts at disc margin often have associated intervillous fibrin comprising gross lesion

Microscopic.text: Early: Collapse of intervillous space with cessation of maternal perfusion, smudging of syncytiotrophoblast nuclei ± neutrophils in intervillous space
Remote: Intervillous fibrin/fibrinoid deposits between pale ghosts of necrotic villi
Infarction hematoma: Round focus of hemorrhage surrounded by infarcted villi
Infarcts associated with other changes of maternal vascular malperfusion: Decidual arteriopathy, distal villous hypoplasia, accelerated villous maturation, placental abruption

Synonyms.text: Infarction hematoma, rounded intraplacental hematoma, microabruption

Associated Placental Findings.text: Changes of maternal vascular malperfusion, including small-for-gestational-age placental growth, decidual arteriopathy, distal villous hypoplasia, accelerated villous maturation, placental abruption

General Features.text: Recent infarcts are dark red and firm
As they age, infarcts lose fetal hemoglobin and become increasingly yellow, then tan-gray to white, remain firm
Infarcts at disc margin often have associated intervillous fibrin comprising the gross lesion
Infarction hematomas are rounded intraplacental hemorrhages ± rim of firm, infarcted parenchyma on gross exam

Excessive Perivillous Fibrin Deposition.text: Localized excess of perivillous fibrin has gross and histologic overlap with infarcts

If > 50% of lesion is intervillous fibrin, may diagnose excessive perivillous fibrin deposition and not infarctMarginal infarcts and excessive perivillous fibrin are often both present in same gross lesion
sub_points: Marginal infarcts and excessive perivillous fibrin are often both present in same gross lesion

Terminology.text: Congenital absence of ganglion cells (aganglionosis) in both nerve plexuses for variable length proximally from anus
Defective peristalsis, functional intestinal obstruction

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Failure of neural crest-derived ganglion cell precursors to caudally migrate or differentiate during embryogenesis
Associated congenital abnormalities (5-30% of cases)Trisomy 21 (in ~ 10%), cardiac defects, CNS anomalies
sub_points: Trisomy 21 (in ~ 10%), cardiac defects, CNS anomalies

Definitions.text: Inherited lysosomal enzyme deficiencies that cause glycogen accumulation, resulting in cellular dysfunction with progressive damage of liver, heart, and skeletal muscle; mode of inheritance autosomal recessive or dominant

Inherited Enzyme Deficiency.text: Glycogen storage disease II (Pompe disease): Acid α-1,4-glucosidase (GAA) > 600 pathogenic variants
Glycogen storage disease III (Cori disease): Glycogen debranching enzyme (GDE); amylo-1,6-glucosidase and 4-α-glucanotransferase activity
Glycogen storage disease IV (Andersen disease): α-1,4-glucan 6-glycosyl transferase
AMP-activated protein kinase deficiency: γ-2 regulatory subunit of enzyme controlling uptake of glucose (PRKAG2)

Definitions.text: Idiopathic granulomatous disorder involving skin or subcutaneous tissue

Presentation.text: Single or multiple asymptomatic papules or subcutaneous nodules
Papules are pink-red to brown-purple, 1-2 mm, in annular arrangements
Literature both supports and refutes reported disease associations and triggersDiabetes, infections, trauma, malignancy, drugReported associations seen more often in adults
sub_points: Diabetes, infections, trauma, malignancy, drug
Reported associations seen more often in adults

Presentation.text: Clinical variants: Localized, generalized, perforating, and subcutaneous
Localized GAMore common in children and young adultsHands, feet, arms, and legs
sub_points: More common in children and young adults
Hands, feet, arms, and legs

Presentation.text: Generalized GAMore common in adultsMacules, papules, or nodules are distributed over limbs and trunk
sub_points: More common in adults
Macules, papules, or nodules are distributed over limbs and trunk

Presentation.text: Perforating GAGrouped papules with central umbilication located on extremities
sub_points: Grouped papules with central umbilication located on extremities

Treatment.text: Intralesional or topical corticosteroids are most commonly used

Prognosis.text: Spontaneous regression over months to years, but lesions may recur

Rheumatoid Nodule.text: Fibrinoid collagen degeneration, more eosinophilic in color
Serologic evidence of IgM rheumatoid factor

Necrobiosis Lipoidica.text: Central zone of degenerated collagen surrounded by palisading granulomatous inflammation
Layers of altered collagen; mucin not prominent
Seen in young adults, rare in children

Epithelioid Sarcoma.text: Malignant cells show loss of INI1
Histocytes of GA will express CD68 and show retained nuclear expression of INI1

Interstitial Granulomatous Dermatitis.text: Eosinophils and neutrophils present, clinical history important

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Majority of minimal change disease (MCD) is idiopathicMain pathogenesis: Thought to be T-cell dysregulation and associated cytokine/small molecule releases and B-cell activation
sub_points: Main pathogenesis: Thought to be T-cell dysregulation and associated cytokine/small molecule releases and B-cell activation

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Secondary forms due to infections, drugs, autoimmune diseases, allergy, and neoplasms

Clinical Issues.text: Common in young children (peak: 2-3 years); M:F = 2:1
Nephrotic syndrome (NS), edema, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia/lipiduria, and susceptible to infections (rarely, hematuria, hypertension, renal dysfunction, and thrombosis)

> 90% of MCD responds to steroid therapySteroid-resistant NS (10-20%): Kidney biopsy indicated [1/4 are focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)]Frequently relapsing/steroid-dependent NS: Steroid therapy or alternative treatments for steroid toxicity
sub_points: Steroid-resistant NS (10-20%): Kidney biopsy indicated [1/4 are focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)]
Frequently relapsing/steroid-dependent NS: Steroid therapy or alternative treatments for steroid toxicity

Microscopic.text: Glomerulus normal by light microscopy except for variable podocyte hypertrophy
Resorption droplets in tubules

Ancillary Tests.text: Immunofluorescence: Negative; minority has faint (≤ 1+) staining in mesangium for IgM ± C3
Electron microscopy: Podocyte foot process effacement, normal glomerular basement membrane, and no deposits

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Examination at multiple levels may detect early FSGS (corticomedullary junction 1st affected)

Synonyms.text: Idiopathic minimal change nephrotic syndrome (NS), minimal change glomerulopathy, minimal change NS, minimal change glomerulonephritis, minimal change nephropathy, light negative glomerulonephritis, Nil disease, lipoid nephrosis

Definitions.text: Idiopathic glomerular disease that causes NS with little or no light or immunofluorescent microscopic abnormalities, negative immunofluorescent staining, and podocyte foot process effacement (FPE) on electron microscopy
Absence of immunoglobulin and complement deposition in glomeruli

Idiopathic (Primary) MCD.text: Pathogenesis of MCD is unknown; thought to be multifactorial; role of T cells and B cells has been proposedT-cell dysregulation is caused by imbalance in T-cell effectors {e.g., abnormal T-cell subsets [CD8(+) > CD4(+)], NK cells, Th2, Th17, and associated cytokines}T-cell dysregulation leads to T-regulatory cells (Tregs) abnormalities, release of cytokines and small molecules [e.g., B7-1 (CD80), c-Mip, oxidants, CD40/CD40L, TNF, uPA/suPAR, angiopoietin-like 4], and B-cell activation [therefore, anti-CD20 antibodies (e.g., rituximab) are effective] that injure podocytes
sub_points: T-cell dysregulation is caused by imbalance in T-cell effectors {e.g., abnormal T-cell subsets [CD8(+) > CD4(+)], NK cells, Th2, Th17, and associated cytokines}

T-cell dysregulation leads to T-regulatory cells (Tregs) abnormalities, release of cytokines and small molecules [e.g., B7-1 (CD80), c-Mip, oxidants, CD40/CD40L, TNF, uPA/suPAR, angiopoietin-like 4], and B-cell activation [therefore, anti-CD20 antibodies (e.g., rituximab) are effective] that injure podocytes

Presentation.text: Sudden (days) onset of NS

Presentation.text: Thrombosis: Rare (2.7%) in children (24.1% in adults): Due to hypercoagulability, hyperlipidemia, and hemoconcentration

Drugs.text: DefinitionsComplete remissionResolution of proteinuria defined as urine protein:creatinine ratio (UPCR) based off 1st morning void or 24-hr collection of ≤ 20 mg/mmol (0.2 mg/mg) or negative urine dipstick or trace protein on 3 consecutive daysPartial remissionDecrease in proteinuria with UPCR based off 1st morning void or 24-hr collection of > 20 but < 200 mg/mmol and, if available, serum albumin ≥ 30 g/LRelapseRecurrence of nephrotic-range proteinuria following either complete or partial remissionSteroid-resistant NSNS resistant to steroid therapy, defined by absence of complete remission after initial course of daily prednisone therapy (60 mg/m² per day)Frequently relapsing/steroid-dependent NS≥ 4 relapses/year or ≥ 2 relapses in initial 6 months after diagnosisSteroid-dependent NS: Relapsing during taper or within 2 weeks of discontinuation

Prognosis.text: Primary (idiopathic) MCDIn children, after remission of 1st episode of NS, ~ 30% do not relapse for 18-24 months; 20-30% progress to infrequent relapses (< 4 episodes in total), 40-50% with frequent relapse or steroid-dependent NS, 10-20% with steroid-resistant NSAlmost all patients with steroid-sensitive NS have excellent outcomeFew patients develop late steroid-resistant NS, chronic kidney disease, or ESRDSteroid-resistant NSKidney biopsy is indicatedKidney biopsy shows MCD in 1/4 of patients and FSGS or mesangial proliferation in most of remaining patients: These patients are at increased risk of ESRDAdults with MCD and acute renal failure (due to hypovolemia) also usually fully recover
sub_points: In children, after remission of 1st episode of NS, ~ 30% do not relapse for 18-24 months; 20-30% progress to infrequent relapses (< 4 episodes in total), 40-50% with frequent relapse or steroid-dependent NS, 10-20% with steroid-resistant NS

Diffuse Mesangial Hypercellularity.text: IF may show IgM or C3

IgM Nephropathy.text: Considered to be variant of MCD by some renal pathologists; occurrence as familial disease may suggest distinct entity
Diffuse, global mesangial IgM staining is present on IF at moderate intensity or greater (≥ 2+)
C3 deposits may also be seen (30-100% of cases), sometimes accompanied by other immunoglobulins
EM shows FPE and occasional scanty paramesangial deposits
Hematuria and hypertension more common than in MCD
6x increased rate of progression to FSGS in children compared with MCD

IgA Nephropathy.text: Usually not difficult because of prominent mesangial IgA deposits and electron-dense deposits in mesangium
MCD superimposed on IgA nephropathy diagnosis should be entertained if NS is of rapid onset and complete FPE is present

C1q Nephropathy.text: May display MCD-like lesion with podocytopathy, typically accompanied by NS (generally unresponsive to steroids) and hematuria in ~ 40%
Dominant C1q in mesangium (≥ 2+) ± immunoglobulins on IF distinguishes from MCD (sometimes can be "full house")
Occasional electron-dense deposits can be found on EM, further differentiating C1q nephropathy from MCD
No diagnostic evidence of lupus nephritis (e.g., autoantibodies, extrarenal manifestations, tubuloreticular structures, etc.)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Examination of biopsy at multiple levels may detect early FSGS (corticomedullary junction 1st affected)
Chronic changes may indicate FSGS in children
Acute tubular injury (from intravascular hypovolemia) may be present and account for acute renal failure
Podocyte hypertrophy (basophilia and smudged chromatin) and tubular reabsorption droplets in otherwise normal biopsy are clues to diagnosis

Terminology.text: Biliary atresia (BA); involves both extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts
Isolated intrahepatic biliary atresia not an entity
Best designated simply as biliary atresia

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Idiopathic, multifactorial (viral infections, developmental anomalies, environmental toxins, immune dysregulation)

Clinical Issues.text: Incidence higher in East Asia (1:5,000-1:10,000) than Europe and North America (1:15,000-1:20,000)
Clinical triad: Persistent neonatal jaundice beyond 2 weeks of age, dark urine and acholic pale, stools, hepatomegaly
20% of patients have extrahepatic congenital anomalies
Cholestatic pattern with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, γ-glutamyl transferase normal or high (not low)
If untreated, fatal by 2 years of age
Hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure) performed by 45-60 days of age has best outcome
Liver transplantation for children not amenable to Kasai, or with failed or nonfunctioning Kasai

General Features.text: Cut surface often shows soft consistency, can resemble brain tissue, and is uniformly pale gray, tan, or pink
Tumors with prominent stromal component are firm with whorled cut surface
Foci of hemorrhage and necrosis and cystic change are common

Specimen Handling and Sections to Be Sub.text: All pediatric renal tumor specimens must be weighedWeight determines decisions about therapy in some cases, e.g., no chemotherapy in younger patients with stage I tumor and total kidney weight < 550 g
sub_points: Weight determines decisions about therapy in some cases, e.g., no chemotherapy in younger patients with stage I tumor and total kidney weight < 550 g

Specimen Handling and Sections to Be Sub.text: Before opening specimen, perihilar and perirenal lymph nodes should be identified and sampledLack of pathologic evaluation of lymph nodes excludes some (otherwise qualifying) patients from "no chemotherapy required" approach
sub_points: Lack of pathologic evaluation of lymph nodes excludes some (otherwise qualifying) patients from "no chemotherapy required" approach

Specimen Handling and Sections to Be Sub.text: Areas with suspected ruptures should be inked in colors different from color choice for true margin
Specimen should be fixed overnight, after taking sample for tumor banking and other special studies
Sampling from renal sinus and margins of resection are essential for adequate staging
Most sections taken from tumor must include tumor-renal parenchyma interface to evaluate tumor borders
Documenting exact site from which each block is obtained is necessaryOften critical for evaluating focal vs. diffuse anaplasia and for addressing staging issues in some cases
sub_points: Often critical for evaluating focal vs. diffuse anaplasia and for addressing staging issues in some cases

Histologic Features.text: Most characteristic: Triphasic pattern consisting of undifferentiated blastema and epithelial and stromal componentsMany tumors have only biphasic or monophasic features
sub_points: Many tumors have only biphasic or monophasic features

Histologic Features.text: Most components in WT correspond to structures at various stages of nephrogenesis

Blastemal cells: Small, closely packed, mitotically active cells with scant cytoplasm, overlapping nuclei, evenly distributed coarse chromatin, and usually small nucleoliCan resemble other "small round blue cell tumors" of childhoodBlastema can be arranged in serpentine, nodular, or diffuse patternTumors with diffuse blastemal pattern often have infiltrative margins, unlike most other types of WT
sub_points: Can resemble other "small round blue cell tumors" of childhood
Blastema can be arranged in serpentine, nodular, or diffuse pattern
Tumors with diffuse blastemal pattern often have infiltrative margins, unlike most other types of WT

Histologic Features.text: Epithelial components: Ranging from primitive rosette-like tubules to well-formed maturing and mature tubules; ill-formed glomerular structures and variable papillary architectureTubules are lined by primitive columnar or cuboidal cells with elongated nucleiMucinous, squamous, neural, or endocrine differentiation may occasionally be present
sub_points: Tubules are lined by primitive columnar or cuboidal cells with elongated nuclei
Mucinous, squamous, neural, or endocrine differentiation may occasionally be present

Histologic Features.text: Stromal component: Loose myxoid and fibroblastic spindled cells are commonly seenWT stroma can differentiate along line of almost any soft tissue typeOccasionally, fat, cartilage, bone, ganglion cells, or neuroglia are also seenRarely, differentiation toward soft tissue types is mature and diffuseTumors with combinations of stromal and epithelial differentiation have been termed teratoid WT
sub_points: WT stroma can differentiate along line of almost any soft tissue type
Occasionally, fat, cartilage, bone, ganglion cells, or neuroglia are also seen
Rarely, differentiation toward soft tissue types is mature and diffuseTumors with combinations of stromal and epithelial differentiation have been termed teratoid WT
Tumors with combinations of stromal and epithelial differentiation have been termed teratoid WT

Histologic Features.text: Anaplasia: WTs are categorized into "favorable" and "unfavorable" histology based on absence or presence of anaplasiaLarge hyperchromatic nuclei that are at least 3x larger than blastemal nucleiEnlarged nuclei in skeletal muscle fibers found in stroma are not evidence of anaplasiaLarge hyperdiploid mitotic figuresDo not confuse anaplasia with normal-sized mitotic figures that appear multipolar due to artifact~ 5-6% of WTs show anaplasiaAnaplasia is rare in infants < 1 year of ageUnfavorable histology is seen in 13% of tumors from children > 5 yearsAnaplasia correlates with resistance to chemotherapy and withTP53mutations in tumorOnly diffuse anaplasia clinically/therapeutically important; therefore, differentiation from focal anaplasia essentialExtensive sampling is important: 1 section per cm of tumor or 1 section per 20 g of tumorAnaplasia is considered focal when present onlyIn single/multiple sharply localized regionsWithin primary intrarenal tumor, surrounded by nonanaplastic tumorWith no severe nuclear unrest (pleomorphism and hyperchromasia) in rest of tumorAnd not present in intravascular tumor

Lymphatic/Vascular Invasion.text: Invasion of renal sinus veins or lymphatics considered stage II in both COG and SIOP staging systemsIntrarenal vascular invasion does not upstage tumor
sub_points: Intrarenal vascular invasion does not upstage tumor

Other Small Blue Cell Tumors.text: Differentiation from blastemal WTPresence of nuclear molding, early tubular differentiation with organized nuclear alignment around early lumina is typical of blastemaPresence of true tubular lumina always favors WTImmunostains may be required in small biopsies to exclude other possibilities, including neuroblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and primitive peripheral neuroectodermal tumor
sub_points: Presence of nuclear molding, early tubular differentiation with organized nuclear alignment around early lumina is typical of blastemaPresence of true tubular lumina always favors WT

Immature Teratoma.text: Differentiation from WT with extensive heterologous differentiation (so-called teratoid WT)Teratoma shows organized (organ-like) differentiation (e.g., ciliated epithelium with smooth muscle and cartilage)WT is characterized by random juxtaposition of different tissue typesPresence of nephrogenic blastema with true tubules and other nephrogenic patterns supports diagnosis of WT
sub_points: Teratoma shows organized (organ-like) differentiation (e.g., ciliated epithelium with smooth muscle and cartilage)
WT is characterized by random juxtaposition of different tissue types
Presence of nephrogenic blastema with true tubules and other nephrogenic patterns supports diagnosis of WT

Metanephric Adenoma.text: Differentiation from epithelial-predominant WTUniform, nonoverlapping nuclei with delicate chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli and lack of mitotic figures in metanephric adenomaImmunostain for WT1 may be negative or weak and focally positive in metanephric adenoma vs. usually strong and diffuse in WTCD57 is positive
sub_points: Uniform, nonoverlapping nuclei with delicate chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli and lack of mitotic figures in metanephric adenoma
Immunostain for WT1 may be negative or weak and focally positive in metanephric adenoma vs. usually strong and diffuse in WT
CD57 is positive

Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (Type 1,.text: Differentiation from epithelial-predominant WT with papillary areasPapillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) often with foamy macrophagesGlomeruloid tufts in tumor occasionally with higher grade cytology, including more prominent nucleoli, compared to cells forming tubulesAMACR and CK7 diffuse and strongly positive and WT1 usually negative in papillary RCCIn WT, AMACR negative, CK7 usually negative or focally positive, and WT1 diffuse and strong positive
sub_points: Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) often with foamy macrophages

Presentation.text: Presents as abdominal mass; may be associated with polyhydramnios, premature delivery, and nonimmune hydrops
Hypertension (due to renin production by entrapped renal elements) may be present

Treatment.text: Complete nephrectomy is necessary due to infiltrative nature of classic variant

Prognosis.text: Majority cured with surgery and have excellent outcomeRecurrences and metastases occur in ~ 5-10% of patients, risk factors for which are incomplete excision, cellular histology, stage III or higher, and involvement of intrarenal or sinus vessels
sub_points: Recurrences and metastases occur in ~ 5-10% of patients, risk factors for which are incomplete excision, cellular histology, stage III or higher, and involvement of intrarenal or sinus vessels

sub_points: Solitary, unilateral, characteristically whorled or trabeculated; gray-white to yellow with rather indistinct tumor-kidney interface and softly bulging cut surface

General Features.text: Cysts, hemorrhage, and necrosis common and have no prognostic significance
Cellular type: Often fleshy, circumscribed
Tumor tends to arise centrally within kidney and extensively involves renal sinus

Sections to Be Submitted.text: Tumor-kidney interface, medial extent of tumor
1 section per cm of maximum tumor dimension

sub_points: Classic CMN entraps renal tubules

Clear Cell Sarcoma of Kidney.text: Cellular variant of CMN lacks chicken-wire vascular pattern of clear cell sarcoma of kidney (CCSK), classic pattern
CMN is positive for desmin &/or SMA and vimentin; CCSK is positive for vimentin only
Presence of renal dysplasia (e.g., cartilage) diagnostic for CMN
Presence of variant patterns of CCSK (e.g., myxoid, sclerosing, epithelioid, palisading)
> 1 year old and presence of metastases (other than lung) support CCSK

Wilms Tumor.text: Very rare in infants, especially those < 6 months of age
Blastema-predominant Wilms tumor has very high mitotic rate with numerous apoptotic cells
Compressed pseudocapsule in contrast to extensively infiltrating CMN

Rhabdoid Tumor of Kidney.text: Occasionally, CMN can have unusually prominent nuclei, in which case immunohistochemical stain for INI1 (BAF47), positive nuclear staining in CMN, and absent staining in rhabdoid tumor are diagnostic

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Vast majority of patients < 1 year old, at which age other pediatric renal tumors are less common
Cellular variant has sarcomatous appearance, but complete resection is often curative
Surgical margins need to be evaluated carefully, especially medial (renal hilar) margin

Treatment.text: Treat underlying disease

Depends on type of material aspirated as well as extent of injury
Meconium aspiration is fatal in 5-10% of cases
Mortality is high in acute aspiration of gastric contents

Types of Aspiration Syndromes.text: Airway obstructionCommon in children; foreign objects include vegetable particles (e.g., peanuts), inorganic materials (e.g., beads, teeth, pieces of toys), etc.Foreign object most commonly lodges in right basilar bronchusLarge object can obstruct trachea/larynx, leading to sudden respiratory distress and death if not promptly removedSmaller objects lodge in small airways/alveolar spaces, causing bronchopneumonia &/or diffuse alveolar damageClinical manifestations: Irritating cough, unilateral wheezing, recurrent pneumonia distal to obstruction
sub_points: Common in children; foreign objects include vegetable particles (e.g., peanuts), inorganic materials (e.g., beads, teeth, pieces of toys), etc.

Terminology.text: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Multifactorial developmental disease
Caused by lung immaturity and alveolar surfactant deficiency during 1st week of life

Clinical Issues.text: Affects ~ 20,000 infants/year in USA
Occurs primarily in premature infants
Male predominance (M:F = 2:1)
Early and progressive respiratory distress
Fetal lung maturity tests assist with management
Occurs more frequently in Caucasians

Microscopic Features.text: Eosinophilic, fibrin-rich alveolar deposits
Variable atelectasis and dilation of alveoli
Minimal to absent neutrophilic infiltrate

Etiology.text: Caused by lung immaturity and alveolar surfactant deficiency during 1st week of life
Inborn errors of surfactant metabolism and surfactant dysfunction may cause HMD

Genetics.text: Allelic variants of genes encoding surfactant proteins (SP) SP-A1, SP-A2, SP-B, and SP-C have been associated with HMD
Polymorphisms in ATP-binding cassette transporter protein (ABCA3) have been implicated in autosomal recessive surfactant dysfunction and HMD

Pathogenesis.text: Surfactant deficiency → ↑ alveolar surface tension → atelectasis → hypoxemia → pulmonary vasoconstriction → endothelial & epithelial injury → plasma exudate into alveoli → fibrin ± necrotic cells (hyaline membranes)

Incidence.text: Affects ~ 20,000 infants/year in USA
Most common cause of respiratory failure in newborns

Clinical Issues.text: Indications for transplant include severe heart failure, growth failure or severe activity limitation due to heart failure, intractable arrhythmias, and risk of irreversible pulmonary vascular disease
Post-transplant outcomes are poorer than for cardiomyopathies or ischemic heart disease
Highest risk is in 1st year after transplant
Most common types requiring transplantation are single ventricle lesions, D- or L-transposition of great arteries, and RV outflow tract lesions (e.g., TOF)
56% of transplants in infants < 1 year
3% of adult heart transplants

Definitions.text: Functional fetal heart and vessels are altered in structure from the newborn heart and vessels so that oxygenated blood from the placenta can bypass nonfunctional developing lungs

Circulatory system.text: First organ system to develop in the embryo

Heart.text: By ~ 20 days gestation, left and right heart tubes fuse into a single endocardial tube
By ~ 23 days gestation, heart has a primitive beat
By ~ 8 weeks gestation, through complex loops, septations, and fusions, a 4-chambered heart is created

Vascular system.text: Originates as blood islands that form from mesenchyme within the embryonic disc, body stalk, and yolk sac
Paired arteries and veins from these 3 regions coalesce to form an interconnected vascular network
